ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class gave me a much better understanding of critically reading and writing, and a good background in literary discussion through our conversations about postcolonial literature and ecocriticism.
I learned more about the traditions of post-colonial and world literature, and developed my ability to close read and analyse the ecological present in literary texts.
I learned a lot about evaluating novels from an ecocritical and postcolonial perspective.
I learned about postcolonial ecology, ecocriticism, ecoliterature, and developed my essay-writing skills.
I learned a great deal about postcolonial criticism and ecocriticism from someone who is clearly leading in the field.
This course provided me with useful insight into the field of postcolonial ecocriticism, connecting themes of postcolonial theory with themes from critical literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class is so good!! I think the discussions we had were so interesting, and all of the literature was incredible well-chosen and interesting. One way I think it could be improved is through the workload -- reading a book a week and then the secondary literature on top of that was sometimes a lot, especially when we also had assignments due. But I think some people brought up concerns about the workload in mid-semester evaluations, and Professor Iheka was very responsive and changed some of the assigned readings for the remainder of the semester to make things more manageable, so that was really kind!

The course was incredibly engaging and insightful. I learned so much from this class! However, the reading load only got heavier as the semester went on, which did not coincide well with finals period.

The strength of this class was the reading list. We read excellent novels. The weakness of the class was that sometimes I wish we had spent more time on secondary sources instead of so much literary close readings.
The course was well-structured, but as we moved through the course I felt we could spend more time on secondary sources!

strengths: varied sorts of readings (novels, poems, academic papers), engaging class discussions, well-laid out syllabus (Professor Iheka was very clear about expectations and deadlines)
weaknesses: confusing emphasis on writing while I appreciated Prof. Iheka's guidance in writing a compelling/organized paper, some class time was spent on reviewing very basic aspects of writing (paragraphs, topic sentences, incorporating evidence, etc.) that I felt juniors and seniors (the core students of the course) would already be familiar with

I really enjoyed having the space to talk and learn from my peers who had experience in a variety of different fields. I think this course could have also benefited from short reading responses with the texts we read for us to prepare many of the ideas and motifs we noticed in the book. This could also help us come in with questions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! Especially if you are in Ecology/Environmental Studies, I feel like this class has prompted me to question a lot of the things we have been taught in EVST classes or just in the way we talk about the environment in general, so this class is an excellent place to start thinking critically about it!! I also genuinely enjoyed all of the books we read even though they were a little sad, and I feel like I learned so much about environmental issues but also about talking about literature, so I would highly recommend this class!
Yes, this course is a must-take for anyone interested in post-colonial histories and environmental issues, especially those who have not examined these issues using a literary lens.
Yes! It is a great class for anyone, regardless of whether they are an English or Environmental Studies major.
I would! The material is engaging and unique, and I think ecoliterature definitely deserves more critical and academic attention from students.
Yes, especially anyone looking to read some great new books!
Yes! Very interesting topics, and I loved reading the novels.
